title: Fine-Tuning Whisper for Inclusive Prosodic Stress Analysis
author: Samuel S. Sohn (Rutgers University), Sten Knutsen (Rutgers University), Karin Stromswold (Rutgers University), ...
relevance_why: The paper investigates automatic speech recognition with a focus on prosodic stress, which is directly applicable to Haohe Liu's interests in audio processing and machine learning applications in speech technology. Techniques for enhancing ASR performance for diverse populations could inform similar approaches in Haohe's work on audio generation and manipulation.
background: The study focuses on improving automatic speech recognition systems for diverse speech patterns and neurodivergent populations by analyzing prosodic stress.
contribution: This paper introduces the fine-tuning of OpenAI's Whisper model to recognize phrasal, lexical, and contrastive stress in speech, achieving near-human accuracy in ASR performance and high precision in gender and neurotype classification.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous ASR systems often underperform when faced with diverse speech patterns, particularly due to biases in training data.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work fine-tunes a large model specifically for recognizing diverse prosodic features, expanding its applicability across different populations.

key_innovation: Utilizes a fine-tuning approach on a diverse dataset to enhance the accuracy of prosodic feature recognition in speech, addressing common biases in ASR systems.
real_world_impact: Improvements in prosody-aware ASR could lead to more inclusive communication technologies, allowing neurodivergent individuals to communicate more effectively and enhancing overall accessibility in various applications.
limitations: The low performance in classifying one of the neurotype categories due to class imbalance may impact generalizability.

new_terms.prosody: **Prosody** refers to the patterns of rhythm, stress, and intonation in speech, which contribute to meaning and interpretation.
new_terms.ASR: **Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR)** is a technology that converts spoken language into text, enhancing communication and interaction with machines.
